# Pygmy goat

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![Pygmy goats
resting](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Pygmy_Goat_on_a_Log.jpg/220px-
Pygmy_Goat_on_a_Log.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pygmy_Goat_on_a_Log.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pygmy_Goat_on_a_Log.jpg "Enlarge")

Caramel with black markings

The **Pygmy goat** is a breed of miniature domestic [goat](/wiki/Goat "Goat").
The pygmy goat can be used for many different things and that is why a pygmy
goat is strictly classified as a multi purpose animal as stated on NPGA or
national pygmy goat association. The pygmy goat is quite hardy, an asset in a
wide variety of settings, and can adapt to virtually all
[climates](/wiki/Climate "Climate").[1] Castrated males are called wethers and
can be shown in pet classes. There are also pedigree classes at shows for
entire goats. There are separate [pedigree](/wiki/Pedigree_\(animal\)
"Pedigree \(animal\)") lineages in Europe, Africa, (where they are sometimes
called the **African Pygmy**) and the United States. And this is because there
were only a few hundred pygmy goats imported from Africa around 60 years ago.

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 Appearance
  * 2 Reproduction
  * 3 Origin
  * 4 Housing and care
  * 5 General information
  * 6 References
  * 7 External links

## Appearance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pygmy_goat&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Appearance")]

Females, called does or nannys, weigh 24 to 34 [kg](/wiki/Kilogram "Kilogram")
(53 to 75 [lb](/wiki/Pound_\(mass\) "Pound \(mass\)")) and males, called bucks
or billys, weigh 27 to 39 kg (60 to 86 lb). [Wither](/wiki/Withers "Withers")
height ranges from 41 to 58 cm (16 to 23 in). Castrated billys are called
wethers. In the U.S. Pygmies only come in 7 breed standard approved colors,
and can be categorized into caramel patterned,
[agouti](/wiki/Agouti_\(coloration\) "Agouti \(coloration\)") patterned, and
black patterned. Within these categories, there are caramel with black
markings, caramel with brown markings, brown agouti, grey agouti, black
agouti, black with white markings, and solid black. The faulting matrix allows
for faulting random white markings from moderate to very serious and these
animals will be judged accordingly. White belly bands are not considered
random markings. The U.S. African Pygmy will also only have brown colored
eyes.[2][3]

## Reproduction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pygmy_goat&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Reproduction")]

Pygmy goats are [precocial](/wiki/Precocial "Precocial") and
[polyestrous](/wiki/Polyestrous "Polyestrous") breeders; bearing one to four
young every nine to 12 months after a five-month gestation period. Does are
usually bred for the first time at about 18 to 24 months, although they may
conceive as early as two months if care is not taken to separate them early
from male kids. Breeding under age does often results in c-sections. Newborn
kids will nurse almost immediately, begin eating grain and roughage within a
week, and are weaned by ten weeks of age.

Polyestrous sexual behavior means that they experience heat and can be
freshened (made to come into milk production) year-round. If milking is a
priority, a continuous supply of milk can be obtained by breeding two or more
pygmy does alternately. Some full-size dairy breeds are also noted for
polyestrous sexual behavior.

## Origin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pygmy_goat&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Origin")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Hand_Rearing_-
_Pygmy_Goat.JPG/220px-Hand_Rearing_-
_Pygmy_Goat.JPG)](/wiki/File:Hand_Rearing_-_Pygmy_Goat.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Hand_Rearing_-_Pygmy_Goat.JPG "Enlarge")

Agouti Pygmy Kid being bottle fed

The Pygmy goat was developed from the [west african dwarf
goat](/wiki/West_African_Dwarf_goat "West African Dwarf goat"), a
[landrace](/wiki/Landrace "Landrace") of [Central](/wiki/Central_Africa
"Central Africa") and [West Africa](/wiki/West_Africa "West Africa"), found
most commonly in the [Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon "Cameroon") Valley. They were
taken to Europe primarily by the British during the [colonial
era](/wiki/British_West_Africa "British West Africa"). They were later
imported into the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") from
European [zoos](/wiki/Zoo "Zoo") in the 1950s for use in zoos as well as
research animals. They were eventually acquired by private breeders and
quickly gained popularity as pets and exhibition animals due to their good-
natured personalities, friendliness and hardy constitution. Today, they are
common as back-yard pets and in [petting zoos](/wiki/Petting_zoo "Petting
zoo").[4]

## Housing and care[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pygmy_goat&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Housing and care")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/African_Pygmy_Goat_003.jpg/220px-
African_Pygmy_Goat_003.jpg)](/wiki/File:African_Pygmy_Goat_003.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:African_Pygmy_Goat_003.jpg "Enlarge")

Grey Agouti Pygmy Buck

Pygmy goats are adaptable to most climates. Their primary diet consists of
[greens](/wiki/Grass "Grass") and [grains](/wiki/Grain "Grain"). They enjoy
having items to jump on and may be able to leap onto small
[vehicles](/wiki/Vehicle "Vehicle"). They are also in need of a shed and open
area accessible at all times. They also need a companion, which doesn't
necessarily have to be its own [species](/wiki/Species "Species"). They are
[prey](/wiki/Prey "Prey") animals and should therefore be sheltered in a
predator-proof area -especially at night. Goats require fresh water at all
times or they won't drink it. Pygmy goats are often affectionate if they are
treated with respect. They can also be trained, though it requires quite a bit
of work. It is important to make sure pygmy goats are comfortable and warm
during the winter months.[5] Simple measures such as feeding pygmy goats
[lukewarm](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lukewarm "wikt:lukewarm") water and
lukewarm food, as well as ensuring their living quarters are free from drafts,
can make pygmy goats a lot happier during the winter.[6]

## General
information[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Pygmy_goat&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: General information")]

  * Scientific name: Capra aegagrus hircus[7]
  * Average lifespan: 8–18 years
  * Normal body temperature: 101.5-104 °F (39.1 - 40 °C)
  * Normal pulse rate: 60-90 beats per minute (faster for kids)
  * Normal respiration rate: 15-30 per minute
  * [Rumen](/wiki/Rumen "Rumen") movement: 1-1.5 per minute
  * Gestation period: 145–155 days (average 150 days)
  * Heat ([oestrus](/wiki/Oestrus "Oestrus")) cycle: 18–24 days (average 21 days)
  * Length of heat: 12–48 hours (average 1 day)
  * Weaning age (recommended): 8–10 weeks
  * Males sexually mature: 9–12 weeks
  * Females onset of heat: 3–12 months*
  * Dehorning (by veterinary surgeon): By 7 days
  * [Castration](/wiki/Castration "Castration"): 
    * Using [elastrator](/wiki/Elastration "Elastration") ring: 8 weeks and older (recommended to limit risk of Urinary Calculi)[[1]](http://www.ansc.purdue.edu/SP/MG/Documents/SLIDES/Urinary%20calculi.pdf)
    * Surgical method (by vet): No age limit

  5. **Jump up ^** David Watts. ["Pet Pygmy Goats: Henry and Joey"](http://www.henryandjoey.co.uk/looka.php). _henryandjoey.co.uk_. Retrieved 11 December 2014.
  6. **Jump up ^** Kinne, Maxine. _Pygmy goat care and management_. 1987.
  7. **Jump up ^** ["Speciality Livestock - Agriculture.com"](http://www.agriculture.com/livestock/speciality-livestock/pygmy-goat-profile_293-ar13324). _agriculture.com_. Retrieved 11 December 2014.

qa.question: how long does a pygmy goat live for

nq_12003_5.Query Analysis: The query seeks information about the average lifespan of a pygmy goat.
nq_12003_5.Answer Analysis: The answer provides a range of 8 to 18 years as the average lifespan of a pygmy goat.
nq_12003_5.Document Content Analysis: The document provides general information about pygmy goats, including their adaptability, diet, behavior, care requirements, and various physiological metrics such as normal body temperature, pulse rate, and respiration rate. It also mentions the average lifespan.
nq_12003_5.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document includes the keywords 'pygmy goat' and mentions their 'average lifespan'.
nq_12003_5.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document explicitly states 'average lifespan: 8–18 years', which directly matches the answer.
nq_12003_5.Key Information Matching: The document directly provides the key information requested by the query, which is the average lifespan of a pygmy goat.
nq_12003_5.Can the Document Answer the Query: Yes, the document directly answers the query by stating the average lifespan of a pygmy goat.
nq_12003_5.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides additional context about pygmy goats that could be useful for a broader understanding.
nq_12003_5.Explanation: The document is directly relevant to the query as it explicitly provides the average lifespan of a pygmy goat, which is the exact information the query seeks. Additionally, the document offers supplementary information about pygmy goats that enhances overall understanding.

triviaqa_68785_7.Query Analysis: The query asks for the typical lifespan of a pygmy goat.
triviaqa_68785_7.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that pygmy goats typically live for 8 to 18 years.
triviaqa_68785_7.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses different types of goats, their breeding habits, and the lifespan of does (female goats). It mentions that the 'normal' lifespan of a doe is 11-12 years but also notes that retired does can live longer, ranging from 16-20 years, with an exceptional case of a doe living to 24 years.
triviaqa_68785_7.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'Pygmies' and discusses the lifespan of does.
triviaqa_68785_7.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document includes lifespan ranges that overlap with the answer (11-12 years, 16-20 years, and 24 years).
triviaqa_68785_7.Key Information Matching: While the document does not explicitly state the lifespan of pygmy goats, it provides relevant information about the lifespan of does, which can be inferred to include pygmy goats.
triviaqa_68785_7.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not directly state the lifespan of pygmy goats.
triviaqa_68785_7.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides information about the lifespan of does, which can be used to infer the potential lifespan of pygmy goats.
triviaqa_68785_7.Explanation: The document contains relevant information about the lifespan of does, which can be inferred to include pygmy goats, but it does not directly answer the query about the specific lifespan of pygmy goats. The provided lifespan ranges offer useful context but are not exact matches to the answer.
